Context:
The text provides information about a postgraduate program in Sport and Event Marketing offered at George Brown College's School of Marketing. The key disciplines covered in this program include sport, arts and entertainment marketing, sponsorship activation, event planning and management, integrated marketing communications (IMC), digital media, not-for-profit and cause-related marketing, and financial metrics.

Students in this program will have the opportunity to develop integrated marketing and media plans for various industries, plan and execute events, and evaluate sponsorship activation opportunities. Extracurricular opportunities may include speed mentoring, 5 to Watch, and Canada’s Sports Business Awards. The program is also offered online, with students applying under the code B420.

The work experience requirement for this program includes one semester of either co-op (paid) or internship (unpaid) work term, which occurs after the end of the second academic semester. George Brown College works with employers and industry partners to identify potential work experience opportunities, and students apply for these opportunities through a competitive interview process. Students are also encouraged to pursue self-directed industry work experience opportunities.

George Brown Marketing students have access to membership in two Canadian marketing associations, the CMA (Canadian Marketing Association) and IAB (Internet Advertising Bureau), included in their tuition fees. The CMA membership includes live and online resources.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Sport and Event Marketing Program (Postgraduate) B400 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
The Canadian Marketing Association (CMA) and Interactive Advertising Bureau (IAB) offer membership with various benefits for marketers. CMA membership includes live and online events, professional development opportunities, tools, resources, networking opportunities, and exclusive access to CMA NXT. IAB membership offers student volunteer opportunities, members-only webinars and podcasts, original Canadian digital marketing research, globally accepted digital ad standards, and global standardized courses, certification, and custom workshops.

Graduates from George Brown College's Sport and Event Marketing program can potentially pursue careers in various industries such as amateur and professional sport, e-sports, arts and entertainment, consumer products, retail, tourism, hospitality, financial services, technology, special events, not for profit, business consulting, advertising, sponsorship, digital and experiential marketing. Potential positions include account manager/executive, event co-ordinator, game operations co-ordinator, marketing co-ordinator, partnerships and sponsorships co-ordinator, and ticket sales co-ordinator.

Industry feedback from Dan MacKenzie (Graduate 1997, Sport and Event Marketing), vice-president & managing director, NBA Canada, and Matthew Coorsh, director, Marketing Sponsorships & Brand Management, Scotiabank, highlights the value of interns from this program for hosting organizations.

Additional future study options can be found in the transfer guide. The required courses for graduation are not explicitly stated in the text.
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Sport and Event Marketing Program (Postgraduate) B400 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
To graduate from the B400 program at the college, you need to complete 13 mandatory courses and 1 work experience term. The program spans over two semesters. The following is a list of courses for each semester along with their codes and pre-requisites:

Semester 1:
- COMP 1110: Computer Applications for Marketing (NONE)
- MARK 1027: Marketing Management (NONE)
- MARK 4005: Applied Business Communications (NONE)
- MARK 4030: Sports and Event Marketing Seminar (NONE)
- SPMK 4002: Event Planning and Management I (NONE)
- SPMK 4014: Principles of Sport & Event Marketing I (NONE)
- BUS 4000: Work Experience Prep Course (NONE)

Semester 2:
- SPMK 4017: Nonprofit and Cause-Related Marketing (MARK 1027)
- MARK 4012: Marketing Metrics (NONE)
- SPMK 4007: Event Planning & Management II (SPMK 4002)
- MARK 2044: Principles of Marketing Research (NONE)
- MARK 4025: IMC & Digital Media Fundamentals (MARK 1027)
- SPMK 4018: Principles of Sport & Event Marketing II (SPMK 4014)
- Work Experience Term (COOP 4001 / INTN 4001 / BAWT 4001)

The graduate of this program is expected to demonstrate abilities such as applying marketing concepts to industries related to sports, arts, entertainment, or causes; developing integrated marketing and media plans; planning, executing, and evaluating comprehensive events; creating professional presentations using industry standard software; analyzing and interpreting marketing activities; and more.

Tuition & Fees:
- Domestic Tuition: $4,310.00 *†
- International Tuition: $17,774.00 **†

*Amounts listed are the total of tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees for the first two semesters of programs starting in Fall 20xx (year not provided)
file_path: scraped_pages/programpages2023/Sport and Event Marketing Program (Postgraduate) B400 | George Brown College2023.txt

Context:
Programs starting in Fall 2022: student service and ancillary fees for the first two semesters are listed, subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2023 and at later dates.

Amounts listed for programs starting in Fall 2023: tuition, materials, student service and ancillary fees for the first two semesters are provided. Fees are subject to change for programs starting in Fall 2024 and at later dates.

One work experience semester program: the tuition fee does not include the cost of the Work Experience semester. The Work Experience fee is $500, which covers the cost of the Work Experience Preparation course and work experience semester.

Financial Assistance: this program is approved for OSAP funding, provided the applicant meets OSAP eligibility criteria.

Admission Requirements: college advanced diploma (three-year) or bachelor's degree or demonstrated relevant work experience, English Language Proficiency testing required for international students with no English proficiency test results.

Course Exemptions: some college and university credits may qualify for exemptions, visit the transfer guide for more information.

International Students: visit the International Fees and Related Costs page for more information on fees, the International Admissions page for country-specific admission requirements, and the How to Apply page for application details.

Application: domestic students should apply through Ontario Colleges, international students should apply through the George Brown College Online Application System.

Contact Us: information sessions are held regularly.

Context:
The text provides information on various ways to contact George Brown College for different inquiries. Here's a summary of the extracted information:

1. Domestic Student Admissions: Contact admissions@georgebrown.ca or visit the Admissions section for queries about domestic admission requirements, deadlines, and processes.
2. International Student Admissions: Contact international recruitment representatives by booking a virtual meeting or submitting an inquiry via the International Contact Us page.
3. Fees and Financial Information: For financial inquiries such as OSAP, Bursaries, Scholarships, contact FinAid@georgebrown.ca or visit the Financial Aid section.
4. Entry Advising: Make an appointment to see an Entry Advisor for advice on program options. Review frequently asked questions beforehand.
5. Centre for Business: General inquiries: business@georgebrown.ca, Phone: (416) 415-5000 ext. 2160. For Sport & Event Marketing (B400), contact Peter Widdis (pwiddis@georgebrown.ca) or John Peco (john.peco@georgebrown.ca).
6. Campus: The program is offered at the School of Marketing, located at St. James Campus, primarily at 200 King St. E. and 290 Adelaide St. E., Toronto, Ontario, Canada. Campus tours are available on a regular basis. Sign up today!
